metadata.title: Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder
anatomical location body part affected: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) can affect any organ or system, resulting in a broad array of neurodevelopmental, behavioral, physical, and cognitive impairments and disabilities, as well as congenital anomalies(42)
description: FASD is an umbrella term that encompasses several related syndromes associated with alcohol exposure in utero. FASD is not intended as a clinical diagnosis. In order of severity (highest to lowest), the syndromes are:(1) –fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) –partial fetal alcohol syndrome (PFAS) –alcohol-related  neurodevelopmental syndrome (ARND) –alcohol-related  birth defects (ARBDs) –fetal alcohol effects (FAEs) is considered an obsolete term
The degree of harm to the fetus from prenatal alcohol exposure is influenced by the dose, timing, and pattern of alcohol exposure and the developmental stage of the fetus when exposed(40)
FASD is estimated to cost $10.1 billion annually in the United States(55)

FASD is estimated to cost $9.7 billion annually in Canada(44) –In the province of Alberta, it is estimated that the lifetime (70 years) health services utilization cost per person with FAS is $506,000 and with FASD is $245,000(45)

ICD-10 codes.P04.3: newborn (suspected to be) affected by maternal use of alcohol
ICD-10 codes.Q86.0: fetal alcohol syndrome (dysmorphic) (ICD codes are provided for reference and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Children and adolescents in the United States with FASD may qualify for supportive and rehabilitative services within their school district through an individualized education program (IEP). Infants and young children, typically < 3 years of age, may qualify for state-funded  programs
presentation signs and symptoms: Diagnostic criteria(8,29)(Note: While confirmed alcohol exposure in utero is considered a criterion for diagnostic classification, definitive information regarding alcohol use is not always available) –Institute of Medicine diagnostic criteria(8,29) -FAS -History of prenatal alcohol exposure -Evidence of two of the following facial abnormalities: -Short palpebral fissures -Thin vermillion border (the sharp demarcation between the lip and the adjacent normal skin) -Flat upper lip, philtrum (vertical groove in the middle area of the upper lip), and/or midface -Prenatal or postnatal growth retardation (≤ 10th percentile) -Low birth weight -Poor weight gain unrelated to nutrition -Low weight-to-height  ratio -Evidence of CNS neurodevelopmental deficiencies -Decreased cranial size (head circumference ≤ 10th percentile) -Structural brain abnormalities, including microcephaly, agenesis of corpus callosum, cerebellar hypoplasia, and basal ganglia abnormality. Changes in these CNS structures have been confirmed with neuroimaging techniques(7) -Impaired neurosensory or motor skills -Global cognitive or intellectual deficits either ≤ 3rd percentile or ≤ 16th percentile in three or more of the following domains: -Cognitive -Executive functioning -Motor functioning -Attention or hyperactivity -Social skills -Pragmatic language/speech or other sensory -PFAS -History of prenatal alcohol exposure -Evidence of components of characteristic facial pattern -Evidence of growth retardation, neurodevelopmental deficiencies, or developmental abnormalities not explained by other factors (i.e., genetic, familial, or environmental) -ARND -History of prenatal alcohol exposure -Neurologic or structural brain abnormalities and/or evidence of growth retardation, neurodevelopmental deficiencies, or developmental abnormalities not explained by genetic, familial, or environmental factors -ARBDs -History of prenatal alcohol exposure -Congenital abnormalities of the cardiac, renal, skeletal, ocular, or neurosensory system –FASD 4-digit  code:(6,7) developed to increase the diagnostic precision and more accurately characterize the spectrum of disabilities associated with FASD(6)  -Assessment of four key diagnostic features -Growth deficiency -Facial phenotype -CNS dysfunction -Prenatal alcohol exposure -Ranking of each diagnostic area -4 – significant -3 – moderate -2 – mild -1 – none -Multidisciplinary assessment
Early signs and symptoms(3,6) –Marked developmental delay –Characteristic facial abnormalities –Body growth or head size ≥ 2 standard deviations below mean –Evidence of withdrawal symptoms

Affected domains in FASD(3,6,9) –Cognitive -FAS is a leading cause of intellectual disability -Impaired learning and memory associated with decreased hippocampal size –Sensory -Impaired visual-spatial  function associated with reduced cortical thinning during development -Decreased sensory processing speed –Visual system (type of visual impairment observed is highly associated with the time of alcohol exposure to the fetus)(38) -Microphthalmia and hypoplasia of the optic nerve -Impairments in spatial frequency acuity and contrast sensitivity -Strabismus -Amblyopia -Poor detection of geometric designs -Abnormal saccadic movements –Motor (associated with impaired cerebellar and basal ganglia development) -Mild to moderate delays in motor development -Poor movement quality -Postural, balance, and gait deficits -Increased reaction times –Speech, language, and communication -Delayed speech acquisition -Impaired social communication -Impaired receptive and expressive language –Social skills and adaptive behavior -Impulsive, aggressive behavior -Tendency to display externalizing and internalizing behaviors -Reduced self-regulation  skills –Executive functions -Impaired working memory, reasoning, and planning skills

Guidelines for referral to a FASD team/clinic(4,5) –Known substantial prenatal alcohol exposure –Presence of all three facial features of FAS (i.e., thin vermillion border, short palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum) –Growth deficits: height and/or weight ≤ 10th percentile, adjusted for age, sex, gestational age, and race or ethnicity –Structural -Head circumference ≤ 10th percentile, adjusted for age and sex -Clinically meaningful brain abnormalities observable through imaging  –Presence of a combination of growth deficits, CNS abnormalities, and facial features –Functional -Global cognitive or intellectual deficits in multiple domains -Performance ≤ 3rd percentile (two standard deviations below mean for standardized testing) -Deficits ≤ 16th percentile (one standard deviation below mean) in at least three domains: -Cognitive or developmental ability -Executive functioning -Motor functioning -Attention or hyperactivity -Social skills -Pragmatic language -Memory deficits -Sensory processing –In the United States, the average age of referral to a specialized FASD team is 9½ years. Only one-sixth  of cases are referred before the age of 4 years Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: No contraindications specific to FASD are noted in the literature
Parental consent should be obtained prior to assessment/examination
Patient learning and cognitive abilities should be considered during the therapy process
Proper notification should be made if an unsafe, abusive, or neglectful home situation is suspected

While testing, keep in mind that children with FASD may experience deficits in completing goal-directed  force responses.(52) See Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) and Treatment Summary , below

causes: Alcohol exposure in utero–Alcohol easily crosses the placenta–Alcohol metabolism in a fetus is slower than in an adult, so blood alcohol concentration is higher in a fetus and remainshigh for a longer time–Alcohol interferes with delivery of oxygen and nutrients to developing tissues and organs

Teratogenic effects of alcohol are related to the timing and level of exposure(3,6)–Reduction in drinking before the third trimester may minimize the impact of alcohol exposure on fetal development–Alcohol consumption in the first trimester may be associated with higher incidence of organ and musculoskeletalabnormalities(3)–Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks in two hours,(10) is linked to greater damage to the developing fetus(29)–Alcohol consumption dose-related  effects have been observed in intellectual and motor performance deficits
Genetic factors include sensitivity to alcohol and the rate at which alcohol is metabolized in the mother and fetus
pathogenesis: Alcohol is a teratogenic agent, disrupting fetal development depending on the time and extent of exposure(4,6,8)–Neurotransmitter (including GABA, glutamate, dopamine, and serotonin) functions are altered by alcohol exposure and/orwithdrawal, and may underlie structural and functional deficits expressed in FASD(11)

Structural abnormalities in FASD(6,7)–Reduced brain volume(12) and density of white matter–Asymmetry of hippocampus and decreased hippocampal size(6)–Decreased basal ganglia size(12)–Abnormalities in cortical thickness in the temporal, parietal, occipital, and frontal lobes occur during development(6,7)–Hypoplasia or agenesis of corpus callosum(7)–Altered neurotransmitter profile in the frontal cortex and basal ganglia(11)

Functional abnormalities in FASD(6,9)–Altered activation pattern in prefrontal and temporal regions during verbal learning tasks in children with FAS comparedto controls–Differences in occipital-temporal  activation in young adults during sustained attention tasks–Altered activation in the prefrontal, parietal, and other structures during working memory tasks in children
risk factors: Alcohol consumption during pregnancy—There is no known safe amount of alcohol consumption during pregnancy–Based on data collected between 2015-2018  from the National Survey on Drug Use and Health, in the United States,64.7% of women in their childbearing years reported using alcohol within the past year.Current drinking (at least onedrink within the past 30 days) was reported by 19.6% of pregnant females in their first trimester, with 10.5% reportingbinge-drinking  episodes(13)-Approximately 50% of all pregnancies in the United States are unplanned; therefore, prenatal alcohol exposure mayoccur unknowingly(13)–Similar rates of alcohol use have been noted in other populations(14,29)–Researchers in Sweden used seven focus groups to discuss alcohol consumption and its relation to pregnancy with 34women (ages 17–34,  who were neither pregnant nor mothers), and came to the following conclusions:(51)-Societal expectations regarding alcohol consumption change with pregnancy, when women are expected suddenly toabstain-The women shared an attitude of zero tolerance for alcohol consumption during pregnancy, but admitted to not knowingmuch about the consequences of alcohol consumption during pregnancy and expressed a desire for more information-The authors encouraged more public health initiatives to educate young women on FASD

Alcohol usage factors–Blood-alcohol  concentration-Binge drinking during pregnancy, or a higher number of drinks consumed daily or within a specified time intervalduring pregnancy, is associated with greater risk of FASD(29)-The greater the blood alcohol concentration, the greater the impact on the neonate(3,29)–Frequency—Consumption of alcohol throughout the term of gestation compared to consumption of alcohol during asingle trimester or part of a trimester is associated with more severe involvement(6)–Timing-Alcohol consumption during the first trimester is associated with more severe involvement, including the presence offacial abnormalities(3)–Critical development periods for various CNS structures may be impacted by heavy drinking or chronic alcoholconsumption throughout pregnancy(1,6,8)
Health status(15,29)–Maternal age (> 25 years)–Three or more previous children–Previous drug use
Societal factors–Local tolerance of heavy drinking
Familial factors(15,29)–Alcohol use or misuse in family–Poor developmental environment (abuse, neglect)
Genetic(15)–Rate of alcohol metabolism in mother and fetus

contraindications precautions to examina: No contraindications specific to FASD are noted in the literature
Parental consent should be obtained prior to assessment/examination
Patient learning and cognitive abilities should be considered during the therapy process
Proper notification should be made if an unsafe, abusive, or neglectful home situation is suspected

While testing, keep in mind that children with FASD may experience deficits in completing goal-directed  force responses.(52) See Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) and Treatment Summary , below

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology of illness -Indicate diagnosis of child (i.e., FASD, FAS, PFAS, ARND, ARBDs) -At what age were symptoms first noticed? At what age was the condition diagnosed? -What are the current signs and symptoms that are impacting the child’s abilities? -Reason for presentation to therapy?

course of treatment.medical management: Who makes up the patient’s medical team? How frequently does the patient followup with each healthcare professional? Are social services involved in the plan of care? Has the patient required any hospitalizations for injuries or illnesses?
course of treatment.medications: Document current and past drug therapy Pharmacologic interventions for children with FASD are symptomatic or for secondary conditions. The child’s response to pharmacologic treatment of comorbid diagnoses (e.g., ADHD) may be different than that of children without FASD
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  There are no definitive diagnostic tests for FASD
Diagnosis is based on a combination of evidence of prenatal alcohol exposure, facial abnormalities, prenatal or postnatal growth abnormalities, and CNS neurodevelopmental deficits
See Presentation/signs and symptoms , above, for diagnostic criteria of FASD
Comprehensive neurodevelopmental testing can identify specific domain impairments in FASD
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Alternative treatments should be documented and effectiveness noted
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech and language, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions, and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document functional domains with identified impairments
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, ease of going to sleep
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could indicate the need for a physician referral (e.g., gastrointestinal, nutritional, sleep disorder) -Children with FASD are at risk for nutritional deficiencies and poor eating habits -Based on a small U.S. study of 19 children with FASD (mean age of 9.6 years), researchers identified the followingconstant snacking (36.8%), lack of satiety (26.3%), and picky eating/poor appetite (31.6%). Constipation was reported in 26.3%of subjects. Fifty-seven  percent of parents reported that their children ingested excessive amounts of sugar(140% to 190% of daily recommendation)(43)Cognitive impairments are common in FASD -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If yes, describe _________________________ -See Assessment/Plan of Care  below for more details regarding cognitive impairments

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient or parent/caregiver about other problems, including ADHD, autism, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, cognitive impairments, substance abuse, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient or parent/caregiver about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the child participate in recreational activities or sports?  -Does the child participate in social activities with peer group members? Impaired social skills and cognitive abilities can impact the patient’s ability to make and sustain meaningful relationships. Individuals often prefer younger friends, act immature, and have difficulty empathizing with others(5,56) -Does the child attend school (home or traditional setting)? What grade? Is there an IEP in place? If so, what services and how often are they being provided to the child? Does the child attend after-school  care or day care? -For older children and adults, does the patient have a history of problems in school, problems with the law, any substance abuse? If so, describe. What treatment interventions took place? Were they effective? Is the patient currently involved in any support groups? Does the patient work? What are the job duties?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment Does patient have any assistive or adaptive equipment? Are any modifications necessary?
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environmentStairs, number of floors in home, living quarters, play area, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?Identify with whom patient lives. Is there a history of foster/government care? Is respite assistance available for primary caregiver? Identify other caregivers who may be present. Are caregivers/family supportive and capable of providing the care and interventions required for the patient?

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.):  Evaluation of an individual with FASD or a related condition is dependent upon the age of the individual. Assessment of multiple systems may be required to generate a full profile of the patient. A team approach, including physical, occupational, and speech therapy, along with psychological, nutritional, and medical assessments, is recommended. The information below is intended to serve as a guide •Adaptive behavior  (16,55) –Impairments in adaptive behavior include social skill deficits, disruptive behavior, hurting self and others, impulsive/ uncooperative behavior, and decreased self-regulation –Common tests -Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Second Edition(19) -Adaptive Behavior Assessment Scale (ABAS)(17) -Fetal Alcohol Behavior Scale(18) -Scales of Independent Behavior(19)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Assess patient’s height, weight, head circumference, cephalic index, and BMI. Compare to age and sex norms. Children with FAS typically present with decreased head circumference, height, and/or weight, which can resolve during childhood(5,6) –Decreased weight can be associated with poor oral motor control that affects the infant’s ability to suck.(5) –As children age, they are at risk for obesity due to poor eating habits and lack of satiety(43) –Facial feature abnormalities, including short palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum, and thin upper lip, are found in FAS. Some aspects of these features may be noted in other forms of FASD(5,6) –Clinodactyly of the toes or camptodactyly/hypoplasia of the fingers may be present and should be assessed(6)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess child’s ability to perform static and dynamic sitting and standing balance with and without perturbation –Use age-appropriate  balance tests, such as the Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS), the balance sections of the Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2),  or the Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2) –Deficits in balance and postural control(22) have been reported in children and adolescentswith FASD and should be assessed –Visual impairments can impact a patient’s balance Executive functioning –Defined as a group of cognitive abilities that include self-regulation,  planning and sequencing of behaviors, cognitive flexibility, and response inhibition. These skills allow an individual to manage his/her own life tasks(55) –Executive functioning tests should be selected according to the developmental and/or chronologic age of the patient -Delis-Kaplan  Executive Function System(23,24) -Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)(24,25) -Wisconsin Card Sorting Test(26) –Individuals can have poor organization and planning, lack of inhibition, difficulty understanding cause and effect, difficulty following multistep directions, impaired ability to adapt to new ways of thinking or changes in routine, poor judgment, and inability to apply knowledge to new situations(5,55)Document patient’s ability to perform age-appropriate  functional mobility skills. Use the WeeFIM, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait dysfunction should be documentedDocument existing joint abnormalities and presence of ROM limitations Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Children exposed to alcohol in utero present with varying degrees of impaired coordination and muscle control as a result of neurological damage(5,6) –Assess for muscle tone in bilateral extremities and trunk -Assess for spasticity using the Modified Ashworth Scale. Note any abnormality or asymmetry –Document the presence of any tremors, ataxia, or lack of coordination with movement. Observe for motor impairments related to cerebellar dysfunction, including incoordination, tremors, and ataxia.(6)Common tests are finger-to-nose, heel-to-shin,  rapidalternating movements for upper and lower extremities, and thumb-to-finger apposition –Assess patient’s ability to perform age-appropriate  gross and fine motor bilateral coordination activities such as jumping, skipping, throwing/catching/kicking, jumping jacks, buttoning, and completing puzzles. Note any asymmetry or delay in movement patterns –Using a goal-directed  force matching task, researchers in the United States found that alcohol-exposed  children had shorter duration of open-loop  control, a higher open-loop  phase rate of force development, a shorter time to reach maximum force during the closed-loop phase, and greater absolute target force error when compared to children without heavy prenatal alcohol exposure(52) -Based on a study of 19 children with and 23 children without heavy prenatal alcohol exposure -Open loop is shorter duration, pre-programmed motor commands whereas closed loop includes longer duration responses with moment-to-moment,  visually guided, on-line  corrections -The authors made suggestions for treatment based on these findings, which are presented in the  Treatment summary below
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: A comprehensive musculoskeletal examination is recommended to document the contribution of muscle weakness to developmental delays associated with FASD(6) Neuromotor development –Gross and fine motor skills need to be formally assessed. Hypotonia, persistent reflexes, impaired motor control, decreased strength, and decreased motor planning can impact an individual’s ability to perform age-appropriate  skills –Use the Bayley Scale of Infant Development, Third Edition (BSID-III),  Neurological Assessment of the Preterm and Full-Term  Newborn Infant, PDMS-2,  BOT-2,  Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Second Edition(19)  –Individuals can present with difficulty writing or drawing, impaired dexterity, or delayed walking and jumping(6)
observation inspection palpation includi: Impaired visual-spatial  processing and sensory processing speed and efficiency are common in FASD. Use the BOT-2 (Visual Motor Subscale) or Developmental Test of Visual Motor Impairment
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess sitting and standing posture. Note any asymmetry or atypical preferred postural positions, such as posterior pelvic tilt, rounded shoulders, or increased calcaneal valgus. Also note any abnormal posturing of extremities at rest or with movement associated with neurological impairments, spasticity, or increased tone
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM and flexibility of the upper and lower extremities, as well as the trunkAssess deep tendon reflexes for upper and lower extremities. Assess for the presence of Babinski and atonic neck reflex. Hyperreflexia and persistent primitive reflexes may be present
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Self-care/activities  of daily living –Limitations in self-care  have been reported in individuals with FASD –Use the Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Index(PEDI), a questionnaire that assesses functional disabilities in children aged 6 months through 7 years, 6 months(19) –Use the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (Peds QL) for children aged 2 to 18 years(19)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess a child’s sensory processing system using the Sensory Profile, Sensory Integration and Praxis Test (SIPT), or Test of Sensory Function in Infants (TSFI)(19) –Assess lighttouch, pinprick, joint proprioception, and stereognosis for extremities, noting any asymmetry or impairments –Hypo-  or hyper-responsiveness  to touch or taste is common(5) –Sensory processing deficits may contribute to impairments in other domains, such as cognition, adaptive behavior, and attention(6)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Comprehensive testing of multiple domains is often conducted when FASD is suspected or indicated. Domain-specific  and age-appropriate standardized tests that are validated and reliable should be used for assessment
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Assess patient’s ability to follow multistep commands. Does the patient make sustained eye contact? Is the patient alert and oriented x 4? –Does the patient have difficulty transitioning from tasks? Is the patient able to adapt to new routines with ease? Is the patient overreactive and has difficulty “calming down”? –Areas of concern include intellectual capacity, hyperactivity, distractibility/short attention span, poor short-term  memory, impaired problem solving, difficulty completing a task, difficulty following multistep commands, difficulty with transitions from one task to another, and impaired ability to respond appropriately to nonverbal communication/facial expressions of others(5,55) –Test to measure attention and hyperactivity -Conners Rating Scales–Revised(20)  –Test of learning and memory -Pediatric Early Elementary Examination (PEEX)(21)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
FASD may be associated with behavioral and/or cognitive challenges that limit an individual’s ability to participate in structured and/or rehabilitation programs

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Earlyintervention is associated with better outcomes in children with FASD. Indications of FASD in a child may include abnormal muscle tone, poor coordination, and difficulty with sucking/swallowing, irritability, inconsolability, abnormal reflexes, low birth weight, facial abnormalities, failure to thrive, and feeding and sleeping problems. Physical therapy is indicated to increase strength, bilateral coordination, motor control, balance, and functional mobility in order to achieve age-appropriate  motor milestones
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Syndromes that share certain physical features of FASD(4) –Aarskog syndrome –Dubowitz syndrome –Fetal anticonvulsant syndrome –Maternal phenylketonuria (PKU) fetal effects –Noonan syndrome –Toluene embryopathy –Williams syndrome  –Other chromosomal syndromes –ADHD
prognosis: Cognitive deficits and executive functioning impairments impact the individual’s ability to learn new skills, concepts, or tasks. This places the child at significant risk for academic failure. Children with FASD are reported to have poor grades in school (especially math), difficulty attending and completing tasks, and difficulty transitioning from one activity to another. In addition, children often have difficulty establishing peer relationships(55)

Adverse long-term  cognitive and behavioral impairments(6,56) resulting from FASD can include: –increased risk of cognitive and psychological impairments requiring dependent care –cognitive and behavioral difficulties impacting learning and academic abilities –increased risk of criminal behavior, incarceration, psychiatric admission, drug/alcohol dependency, and homelessness –chronic unemployment or underemployment
A poorer QOL and higher levels of psychiatric and behavioral problems have been reported in individuals with FASD compared to other at-risk  populations(54)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Speech language therapy Social work/family support services Occupational therapy Psychology Neuropsychology Behavioral therapy Resource specialist within the school setting
other considerations: Experimental therapeutic interventions to minimize the possible impact of alcohol exposure in utero are being explored in animal models. Avenues of investigation include: –neurotransmitter antagonists to potentially prevent activation of receptor sites in developing structures (28) –antioxidants to potentially mitigate damage caused by reactive oxygen following alcohol exposure(28) –nutritional supplementation, including choline supplementation, to potentially attenuate the adverse effects of alcohol(29) -In an RCT (N = 31) conducted in the United States, researchers investigated the impact of choline on neurodevelopment in children with FASD. Results showed that children who received choline had greater nonverbal intelligence, visual-spatial skills, and working memory ability than the control group -Other potential nutrients for supplementation that have been identified are vitamin A, DHA, folic acid, zinc, choline, vitamin E, and selenium(46)

A robotic virtual-reality  platform was shown to be a sensitive and powerful tool in identifying motor problems in children with FASD(47) –The authors tested reaching control in normal children (n = 152) and children with FASD (n = 31) and found that children with FASD had greater upper-limb  instability, more errors in direction within first movement of reach, and more corrective movements that were inefficient
Individuals with FASD may lack a fear of strangers, be easily taken advantage of, and exhibit inappropriate sexual behaviors(5,56)

Researchers in Canada who investigated service provision for individuals with FASD or prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) noted that since children and their parents receive many recommendations, they need access to a wide range of supports and services. It is crucial to ensure that recommendations are in keeping with what is available in the community and also what is feasible to implement(54) –In the study, the recommendations that were implemented and deemed effective overlapped with those reported as valuable for other young populations with disabilities (e.g., autism, ADHD, mental health issues). The authors suggest that although individuals with FASD or PAE may require some specialized services, in general the key element of the assessment is the identification of needs, not diagnosis (a “pan-disability  approach”)
treatment summary: In general, physical therapy and occupational therapy are recommended to address gross and fine motor developmental delays, balance and bilateral coordination impairments, decreased cardiopulmonary endurance, decreased muscle strength and flexibility, difficulty with age-appropriate  self-care  skills, impaired gait, impaired sensory integration, and parent

desired outcomes outcome measures based: Improved motor control and bilateral coordination–WeeFIM, PEDI, PDMS-2,  BOT-2
Improved gross and fine motor developmental skills–BSID-III,  Neurological Assessment of Preterm and Full-term Newborn Infant
Increased balance–PBS–Balance sections of PDMS-2  and BOT-2
Increased ability to attend to and complete tasks with minimal redirection

Improved cognition, problem solving, adapting to change, and generalizability of skills–Age-appropriate  standardized tests of behavior, executive function, and cognitive development-Sensory Integration tests-SIPT-TSFI(19)-Executive functioning-Delis-Kaplan  Executive Function System-Wisconsin Card Sorting-Adaptive behavior-Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Second Edition

maintenance or prevention: Abstinence from the use of alcohol during pregnancy is the only form of prevention Screening for alcohol use once pregnancy is established(35) Interventions for maternal alcohol use during pregnancy may be effective in reducing the risk and/or impact of alcohol exposure(10) Medical communities around the world are advocating that women who are pregnant or who are planning a pregnancy should abstain from alcohol. It is the safest option for the fetus. Examples of countries with these guidelines are the United States, Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom –Researchers in South Africa surveyed 1,047 men and women attending alcohol-serving  establishments and found that pregnant women (n = 53) were less likely to believe that they should not drink alcohol, and also were less likely to believe that alcohol can harm a fetus, when compared to non-pregnant  women (n = 429). Men with pregnant partners had similar findings when compared to men without pregnant partners(48) –Researchers in Western Australia found that among the indigenous population a higher education level was the greatest predictor of safe drinking practices during pregnancy and that having heard of FASD was the greatest predictor of knowledge of outcomes for children with FASD(49)

Prevention Identifying alcohol use during pregnancy and instituting education and treatment protocols aimed at reducing the risk of prenatal alcohol exposure are associated with positive newborn outcomes(30) Factors that may reduce the impact of FASD on a child’s abilities include:(30) –early diagnosis and intervention –involvement in special education and social services –a stable, nurturing home environment –absence of violence

Canadian guidelines released in 2016 recommend the following core diagnostic team across the lifespan of persons with FASD (strong recommendation with high quality of evidence):(53) For infants (< 18 mo.) –Pediatrician/physician  –Child development specialist who has the skill set to conduct physical and functional assessments (e.g., speech-language pathologist, physiotherapist, occupational therapist, clinical psychologist) For preschoolers (18 mo.–5  yr.) –Pediatrician/physician –Occupational therapist –Speech-language  pathologist –Psychologist For school-aged  children (6 yr.–adult) –Pediatrician/physician with expertise in FASD and differential diagnosis –Occupational therapist –Speech-language  pathologist –Psychologist For adults –Physician –Psychologist –Speech-language  pathologist/psychologist with expertise in language assessment

Intervention recommendations may include: Children and adolescents(36) –Community-based  programs –Education support –Family support –Mental health services –Social services –Developmental therapy –Social training Adults(37) –V ocational training –Community living support –Social services –Mental health services –Family and parenting support
patient education: See “Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASDs)” from the U.S. CDC at https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/fasd/
General information and resources at the U.S. Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration website at https://www.samhsa.gov/fetal-alcohol-spectrum-disorders-fasd-center

See “Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD); Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS)” at the American Pregnancy Association website, http://americanpregnancy.org/pregnancy-complications/fetal-alcohol-syndrome/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
